message.body: Hi Edward!
Hello Cashew
What's going on with you today?
not much, busy day. not feeling too good actually
how'd your day going?
s'going pretty well; I've had a solid month and a half of panicked preparation for shows, and I just finished the last of them, so I've been catching up on sleep and enjoying not being overloaded
When you say (type) "not feeling too good", do you me health/sickness-wise?
glad you get a break to catch up
yeah I've got some stuff going on and it makes my stomach upset
that sucks. sorry to flaunt my break in the face of your upset stomach. It's always the worst when you not only have a lot to do, but you're also uncomfortable aside from that while you're doing it.
how did your shows go?
Really well. Friday was predictably really good, and Saturday I was rushed but ended up doing fine.
were they here in the city?
While I was playing I thought a few times that I was bombing, but then people's reaction afterward was extremely positive.
Yeah, they were both in the Fishtown area
Saturday I actually got to play for an "art" crowd for the first time.
Which turned out to be kinda fun.
How'd your weekend go?
nice, fishtown is kind of the art-y part of town
it was okay
In a low-key or going out kinda way?
low-key
nice
Do you tend to prefer keeping things low-key or being in larger social settings?
def low-key
not much for big gatherings
I like to see live music and stuff, but not really into parties where everyone just gets wasted
Yeah, me neither.
For me playing shows is about all the capacity I have for social atmospheres
On Saturday when my friends were leaving and all my gear was set up I had a moment of,
"What am I gonna do; I won't know anybody once you're gone. But at least I can break down my gear.
That'll help me not talk to anyone."
yeah meeting new people is not my strong suit either
Yeah, I feel like I'm okay at doing it when I need to, but at the same time would prefer to sit at home reading on a Friday night.
Also, the "art" crowd doesn't seem to stay much more sober than the Happy Hour crowd when they go out.
There were definitely some wasted people there, maybe a lower percentage...
was it mostly people in their 30s or 20s?
The majority was people around that age, but there were also about 4 or 5 older people, maybe around 60-65
that's cool
I was surprised because 3 of them came up to me and were really blown away by my set
I hate going to things where everyone is college-age
Yeah, I'm starting to feel increasingly old at places like that
Seems more impressive when older people appreciate things, since they have more experience and all
me too
I'm also overly conscious of the age gap with older people because I guess I've seen a lot of older people react really negatively to stuff I've done or that I like
So when I see/meet older people who appreciate art or music coming from less-traversed formats it's relieving to me.
yeah it's funny how some older people are so stuck in their ways and only like stuff from when they were young
and others change with the times
Totally. Funny enough Phillip Glass just came on my iTunes, which is appropriate because
the older folks I was talking to were in him and Edgar Varese and Laurie Anderson in their young adult time period
So they were definitely primed to the weirder side of things, but still it feels good to me to get compared to those artists as opposed to
I don't even know
Like some currently trendy band that I don't listen to
yeah definitely
much more of a compliment if that is the kind of stuff you like yourself
I gotta go
Talk to you later!
cool. talk to you later.
